dict.string: easy to shape or bend
Fortunately, social manners are more malleable and supple than laws and codes.
The mastery-oriented children, on the other hand, think intelligence is malleable and can be developed through education and hard work.
A malleable personality is capable of being changed or trained, and a malleable metal is able to be pounded or pressed into various shapes. It's easier to learn when you're young and malleable.
in good taste, orderly
He is an incisive writer and a disciplined and decorous filmmaker, framing and cutting his scenes with clean, almost classical economy.
He adds: "I'm now married a wonderful, decorous veiled woman and have lovely children, may God save them and her."
Something that is decorous is dignified, proper, and in good taste, like your decorous great-aunt who always wears a dress - even when she's only headed to the grocery store.
to clear all blame or suspicion
show to be right by providing justification or proof
adly, not everyone is able to vindicate their company, nor are individuals, as the case may be.
"We will use all of our resources to vindicate my client's rights and hold those responsible for their actions," Mr. Wigdor said.

Vindicate means to justify, prove, or reinforce an idea - or to absolve from guilt. If your family thinks you hogged the last piece of pie on Thanksgiving, you'll be vindicated when your younger brother fesses up.
to free completely from blame
"We know that excellent analysis of crime evidence can help us identify culprits and exonerate the innocent," he said.
The North Carolina Innocence Inquiry Commission has now helped exonerate eight people since its creation in 2006.

To exonerate someone is to declare him not guilty of criminal charges. This word is pretty much only used in reference to proceedings in a court of law. A word with a similar meaning that might be familiar is "acquit."
to deny
"The system is a complicated system; we don't disavow that. We don't want any case to take long. But sometimes factors make it go on."
"Every area of the law is potentially subject to abuse, but that's not the reason to disavow the law itself," he said
To disavow is to deny support for someone or something. You might feel dissed if your biggest donor decides to suddenly disavow you in your run for president.
rude; cranky; ill tempered
The smart thing for Republicans to do is to just ignore the petulant child in the White House and go about their business.
Among its eight Oscar wins would be one for lead actress Vivien Leigh for her petulant Scarlett.

Choose the adjective, petulant, to describe a person or behavior that is irritable in a childish way. Angry or annoyed mean the same thing, but if you choose the word, petulant, you are indicating that it is unreasonable or unjustified.
n. boldness; recklessness; audacity
They threatened to seek damages from the family of one accident victim, if that family had the temerity to sue.
The town had a basketful of feelings good and bad about Joe's positions and possessions, but none had the temerity to challenge him.

Use the noun temerity to mean the quality of being unafraid of danger or punishment. If you have the temerity to jump off the bridge even after hearing about the risk of instant death, you truly are a nutcase.
including all, or almost all, the items, details, facts, information, etc
This list is far from comprehensive - it's just a sampling of the types of pot-related businesses that are interesting investors at this point.
The insurance system should be designed to financially protect people from low-probability events, rather than provide comprehensive coverage for all health events, as Obamacare envisions.
The city lacks a comprehensive mental-health-care system, and cops are often called to assist people in the midst of psychotic episodes.

When you want to describe something that includes all or most details, you can use the adjective comprehensive. If you get the comprehensive treatment at a spa, it might include massage, manicure and a facial.
vulgar or indecent speech or language, as in a ribald joke
This novelist and this director seem like a natural match: Both share a love for linguistic play and a sly, ribald sense of humor.
The Interview may be, as Corliss writes, a "parade of ribald gags," but Americans, unlike North Koreans, are free to watch such fare.
Ribald is an adjective you would use to describe someone who makes dirty sexual jokes. Vulgar, perverted, but still kind of funny - that's a ribald person.
to attack, especially to attack the truth or integrity
But without meaning to impugn his veracity, or to dispute the register, we may say that he has scarcely got anybody to believe it.
The stated goal was to prevent defense lawyers from using past disciplinary cases to impugn an officer's credibility during court proceedings.

To impugn means to call into question or attack as wrong. If your usually grumpy brother is suddenly nice and sweet, you'll impugn his motives if you're smart — he probably just wants something from you.
likely to cause disagreement between people
liking to argue, involving a lot of arguing
The refusal sets up another confrontation between the automaker and federal regulators in what has already been a contentious issue.
The meeting also heard a presentation that touched on the contentious issue of whether to allow emergency deer feeding during harsh winters.
Perhaps the most contentious aspect of the plan is its price tag
A contentious issue is one that people are likely to argue about, and a contentious person is someone who likes to argue or fight.
able to be done
Most experts agree that remission is feasible, and that, to some degree, we will be able to wean patients off lifelong therapies.
Which could mean that at least for some, Uber is not economically feasible as a full-time job.
If something is feasible, then you can do it without too much difficulty. When someone asks "Is it feasible?" the person is asking if you'll be able to get something done.
the tendency of an organic system to maintain internal stability
Vitamin A has fundamental roles in embryonic development, reproduction, bone metabolism, skin homeostasis and vision.
Alcohol's effect on sleep homeostasis can lead to poorer quality sleep, according to the study published recently in the journal Alcohol.
Homeostasis is a word you learn in biology. It refers to a cell's home state––the way it wants to be, and should be if everything that regulates the cell is working.
to show off; to display ostentatiously
Automakers, realizing that it wasn't socially acceptable to flaunt wealth while others were struggling, rolled out few new ragtop models after the recession.
These people did not flaunt what they had; they paid their debts on time and were generally cautious about overspending.
Flaunt is "to display proudly or show off," like when you flaunt your new Italian leather jacket by wearing it to the beach and pretending you're cold to make sure everyone sees it.
strong taste or liking
The British penchant for horror might reflect the nation's long tradition of public-service broadcasting, which seeks to entertain and inform at once.
Lillian is a free spirit who doesn't worry about "what someone might call moral things," such as her penchant for married men.
A penchant is a strong preference or tendency. If you have a penchant for pizza, you either eat it daily, or wish you did.
inactive; sluggish; not reacting chemically
Even then I kept seeing the soldier's body tumbling toward the water, splashing down hard, how inert and heavy it was, how completely dead.
To Mr. Rose, it's provocative because it maps a sophisticated human emotion, anxiety, onto an inert, or dumb, object
The chubby, inert pet dog has become a familiar household sight in richer countries
Something that's unable to move or moving without much energy can be described as inert. Or when something or someone appears lifeless, the adjective to use is inert.
cheerful readiness; liveliness or eagerness
Her voices, shifting with alacrity from high to low pitches, can seem like manic riffs.
Woog is a bundle of energy, moving with alacrity around the court and peppering his crisp shots with good-natured commentary.
Someone with alacrity shows cheerful willingness and eager behavior, like a kid whose mother has told him he can buy anything in a candy store.
to hide the seriousness of sth with excuses or apologies
lessen or to try to lessen the seriousness or extent of
During the interval of these few hours of abandonment nothing can palliate or excuse, George Borrow died as he had lived-alone!
"The word palliate means 'to remove suffering,'" Anderson says, in whatever form it takes

When you palliate something, you try to make something less bad: Your dentist might give you pain-killing drugs to palliate the discomfort caused by an impacted molar, but that molar is still there, waiting to cause more trouble.
a statement that contradicts itself
a statement containing 2 opposite ideas features that make it seems impossible or unlikely
Managers intent on achieving such self-organization, however, face a paradox: self-organization suggests the absence of management, so what's a manager to do?
It is a paradox that every dictator has climbed to power on the ladder of free speech.
When Oscar Wilde said, "I can resist anything except temptation," he used a paradox to point to our fundamental weakness to give in to tempting things (like chocolate or a pretty smile).

A paradox is a logical puzzler that contradicts itself in a baffling way. Example: "This statement is false." If you think it's true, then it must be false, but if you think it's false, it must be true. Now, that's a paradox!
lenient; yielding to desire
being favorably inclined
Being indulgent towards radical Islamism is the same as being indulgent towards Nazism, he told reporters.
The coming weeks will be packed with parties, treats and indulgent annual traditions.
Tip #3: Stop Being an Over Indulgent Grandparent. I know how tempting it is to shower your grandkids with toys and stuff.
Someone who is self-indulgent gives themselves a lot of treats. Parents who are indulgent cave to ever desire their child expresses. Indulgent means lenient, or overly generous
n. a feeling of intense dislike, hatred;
n. the object of a feeling of intense aversion; something to be avoided
But the G20 summit is an international gathering, convened by members who do not all share the West's antipathy for Russia's president.
And despite Europeans' perceived antipathy toward American tech companies like Amazon and Facebook, the companies continue to have strong followings across the 28-country bloc.
An antipathy is a deep-seated dislike of something or someone. Usually it's a condition that is long-term, innate, and pretty unlikely to change - like your antipathy for the Red Sox.
lacking ideas or intelligence
The state needs more than an "empty, vacuous promise," he said.
It just strikes me as vacuous to automatically liken having tattoos to being a poor student or young adult.
If someone smiles at you in a way that seems fake or empty, you could describe the smile as vacuous. If something is vacuous, it's like a vacuum - hollow, empty, devoid of substance.
stubbornly rebellious or disobedient
"If we cannot make this contumacious rascal speak, we will find others more tractable," observed the pursuivant.
His contumacious agitation against the new order of things led to his imprisonment and ultimate banishment.

That ornery horse that keeps heading back to the barn, no matter how much you coax and kick and try and convince him to stay on the trail? He's showing you his contumacious side, meaning he's stubbornly resisting authority.
n. something not typical; a deviation from the standard
"The short period in which Congress enacted most of the Great Society programs," Zelizer comments, "was more an aberration than the norm."
Management is oblivious; the incident seems to be treated as a bizarre aberration rather than as par for the course for the system.
An aberration is something strange that rarely occurs. An example of an aberration is when the temperature hits 90 degrees in January — it's nice and warm, but it's really strange.
full of energy, excitement and happiness
strong and healthy, growing quickly and well
This show, he says, "includes quiet moments and meditation as well as exuberant playfulness."
"He painted and sculpted with it. In a Caribbean context, with a tropical exuberant landscape, his architecture remains revolutionary.
As night fell across Paris, the quiet and reflective mood of the day turned exuberant and joyful.
Are you feeling really happy and enthusiastic about something? Describe yourself with the adjective, exuberant!
to annoy; to pester; to worry
The Jets' troubles vex Ryan, his coaching staff and the players.
If something vexes you, it brings you trouble or difficulty. In other words, it annoys, worries, distresses, irritates, bothers, or puzzles you.
unfavorable or unfortunate; improper
To be sure, there's nothing unethical or untoward about this; it's just extremely unusual.
Once a month I would go through it and give it a good check to make sure nothing untoward has happened, he said.
The adjective untoward describes something offensive or inappropriate, like the rumors of untoward behavior that can shatter a Hollywood icon's reputation.
spread or diffuse through
Similar sentiments of loneliness, doubt and fear pervade most of Broken Bells' songs.
Having wired up the world, Silicon Valley assured us that the magic of technology would naturally pervade every corner of our lives.
Myths and stereotypes still pervade throughout society and have the potential to influence jurors too.
To pervade means to be present throughout, to exist in every part of. If you have too many cats, the horrible smell of cat pee will pervade your house.
(of a body of water) free from disturbance by heavy waves
not easily irritated
He seemed placid to me on the platform, but something about that stillness makes me wary now.
This is the Loch Ness-monster side of the Web-the unknown something lurking beneath the placid surface.
Call a body of water placid if it has a smooth surface and no waves. Call a person placid if they don't tend to make waves by causing a fuss
to dry out
lacking vitality or spirit; lifeless
Many peasants had abandoned their desiccated farms and moved to slums on the outskirts of the cities, where they became perfect tinder for the revolt.
But as climate change–fueled droughts continue to desiccate California, the short-term solution from farmers has been to double down on making money.
he verb desiccate means to dry out, dry up and dehydrate. It's helpful to desiccate weeds but certainly not crops.
acutely insightful and wise
Of course, some pigeons are more sagacious, cleverer than others; but the fact remains, and everything tends to prove it.
Mr. Jones was a man of the world, and, moreover, was a wise and sagacious man of business.
Use the formal adjective, sagacious, to describe someone who is wise and insightful like an advisor to the president or a Supreme Court justice.
ambiguous; confusing; capable of being interpreted in more than 1 way
As such, Middleberg said the results are "equivocal" -- meaning they neither prove nor disprove that Klein was poisoned.
Cable news channels carrying the equivocal and morally ambivalent remarks used a split screen to show rioters in Ferguson lighting fires and looting store.
Try to remember that uncertain means equivocal and certain means unequivocal. That's a tricky movement the un- is making, and a lot of people get stumped.
a sluggish, gloomy temperament
Dafoe is jagged and saturnine: as he lopes and leers he looks as if he could swallow up the stage.
The death of his adored father sinks the saturnine Turner into an even deeper gloom.

Medieval alchemists ascribed to the planet Saturn a gloomy and slow character. When people are called saturnine, it means they are like the planet - gloomy, mean, scowling. Not exactly the life of the party.
to pacify; to appease; to sooth
One of the ways the Chinese government has always sought to placate its own citizens is by getting tough on foreign businesses.
They provide some credit monitoring to placate consumers, but they have no real incentive to do better.

When a husband shows up with flowers after he's fought with his wife, he's trying to placate her. If you placate someone, you stop them from being angry by giving them something or doing something that pleases them.
to converse, to formally discuss about a subject
an extended communication (often interactive) dealing with some particular topic
With one young woman's life story in the public discourse, the national conversation about Death with Dignity has changed permanently.
The political discourse around immigration, he added, "becomes very heated and very angry and sometimes the rhetoric is not healthy".
If you use the word discourse, you are describing a formal and intense discussion or debate
n. the act of entering some territory or domain (often in large numbers)
n. the mistake of incurring liability or blame
During the incursion, Anonymous hackers swiped credit card numbers, emails, and other information, then distributed the material online.
Russia is feeling financial pain and diplomatic isolation because of international sanctions stemming from its incursion into Crimea and eastern Ukraine, American officials said.
When an army crosses a border into another country for battle, they are making an incursion into enemy territory. An incursion is an invasion as well as an attack.
unwarily simple;; candid; naïve
lacking in sophistication or worldliness
His face had an ingenuous, rather child-like expression, and it acquired a certain character of manliness, thanks solely to a dark red mustache, closely cropped.
Her Swanilda is ingenuous, but also petulant; when she discovers the secret, she's childishly self-satisfied, risking likability in the service of humor.

Someone who is ingenuous shows a childlike innocence, trust, and openness. One of the things kindergarten teachers value is the chance to work with kids while they're still relatively ingenuous - their open, trusting natures are a joy.
distasteful or offensive
After my story was posted, online commenters, both anonymous and identifiable, made morally repugnant and offensive remarks about Lynch.
Katehi called the behavior "repugnant and a gross violation of the values our university holds dear."
Repugnant refers to something you detest so thoroughly it threatens to make you physically sick, like the idea of marrying your sister. Or wearing last year's jeans.
sneaky; secret; marked by quiet and caution and secrecy; taking pains to avoid being observed
conducted with or marked by hidden aims or methods
His video implication after capturing a multitude of Chinese buyers making surreptitious handoffs for cash?
Google Glass garnered plenty of attention, but as a consumer item, it's fallen flat as worries about privacy and surreptitious surveillance prevailed.
When someone behaves in a surreptitious way, they're being secretive. They're doing something that they don't want to be seen doing.
to distribute; assign; allot
The plan didn't allocate enough money to pay for expenses while a debate on extending the state's income tax increase was pushed off
He urged the government to allocate additional funding to help the schools recruit good teachers and leaders.

To allocate is to set aside a certain amount of money for an expense. Aside from money, a common thing to allocate is time: "The old woman had so many children she could only allocate 2.7 minutes per day to talk to each one individually."
harmful
His findings indicate that only uncontrollable stressors cause deleterious effects.
So it is impossible to draw any conclusions about what deleterious effects, if any, hard and prolonged exercise might have on our bodies.
If something is deleterious, it does harm or makes things worse. Smoking has obvious deleterious effects on your health, not to mention your social life.
to subdue and dominate; to enslave
put down by force or intimidation
White South Africans were living in a dream world, he thought, if they believed they could continue to subjugate the majority of the country's population.
White people created the social construct of race to subjugate people of color, so you are the only ones who can change it.
They subjugate women, free speech, freedom of religion - pretty much all of the rights modern, intelligent societies hold dear.
If you say you won't be kept down by the man, you are saying that you won't let the man subjugate you. To subjugate is to repress someone, or to make them subservient to you.
lofty praise
After a round of welcoming speeches – essentially panegyrics for Mr. Karunanidhi's benefit – a microphone was placed in front of Mr. Karunanidhi.
Since she herself has been just such a writer for 50 years, she is the perfect companion for readers of this short, copiously illustrated panegyric.

A formal, high-minded speech can be described with a formal, high-minded word - the word panegyric, which is a very elaborate tribute to someone. In any case, the word today stands for high praise given in a speech or tribute as highfalutin as the word itself sounds.
promoting health
The city has a most salubrious climate, and is free from great extremes both of heat and cold.
The idea being that calories from a vitamin and fiber-packed apple might displace those from less salubrious snacks.
Salubrious is a fancy way to describe something that's good for you or is generally favorable to mind or body, but it need not be limited to describing healthy foods or liquids.
n. an exceedingly large amount
Even if he had his uncle's genius and his uncle's indefatigability, he would sink, as his uncle did, under the exorbitance of his attempts.
An exorbitant action or procedure means that something is much too high; especially excessive or gross deviation from rule, right, or propriety
to measure the depth of sth
Two years later, after Nick Hornby had adapted Strayed's story for the big screen, it was Witherspoon's turn to plumb the author's depths.
But it doesn't deeply plumb the complexities of the text.
To plumb a body of water, you measure its depth. To plumb a house, you connect all of its pipes. To make carpentry plumb, you get it exactly vertical.
pungent; attracting or delighting; engagingly stimulating or provocative
Crisps need to deliver simple, powerful flavours: saltiness, something sharp and piquant, something incredibly umami and savoury, or preferably a combination of all three.
It's a little like white wine, and it has delicious, piquant qualities which I think would go well with fish.

Someone who's piquant engages you with charm and wit. A story that's filled with piquant details has plenty of juicy, provocative points. And grandma's homemade gravy? It's certainly zesty and piquant, even with all the lumps.
scholarly; having or showing profound knowledge
It is a book both erudite and accurate, dazzling in its breadth of knowledge and historical detail.
He is learned, erudite, witty, with an eye for the telling detail.
If you call someone erudite, that means they show great learning. After you've earned your second Ph.D., you will be truly erudite.
demanding prompt action; urgent
In exigent circumstances, or emergency situations, police can conduct warrantless searches to protect public safety.
The policy allows for ICE agents to act if there are "exigent circumstances" such as a national security risk or pursuit of a dangerous felon.
When you describe something as exigent, you are saying it requires attention: it can't be ignored.
to gather or and store
At the same time, those concierge healthcare providers that cater to the super-rich are able to garner significant economic benefits.
Warren points out that while the low-profile jobs may be both necessary and important, they just don't garner the accolades or the money and promotions.
To garner means to gather or earn. If you want to run for office without belonging to a political party, you must garner enough signatures — usually a few thousand — to get onto the ballot.
n. a confused mass; a commotion or turmoil
As described by Mr. Opayemi, who runs a company that imports specialty foods, recent weeks have been a welter of confused and contradictory directives.
Mr. Montgomery's company eventually collapsed in a welter of debts and legal claims.
Use the noun welter to describe an enormous, messy pile, like the jumble of papers, coffee mugs, pens, and food wrappers on the desk of the messiest person in the office.
the quality of a sound independent of pitch and loudness
Mr. Jackson at full volume has a strong, slightly nasal voice whose timbre smooths out when he sings more quietly.
How could it be, when the registrations and rhythms, the play of timbre and chord and dynamic are so very much Carpenter's own?
Timbre is a word that describes the tone or unique quality of a sound. If you play the same note on a piano and on a guitar, each note will have its own timbre.
implied rather than expressly stated
complete without doubt or reserve
We have an implicit assumption that intelligence and rationality go together-or else why would we be so surprised when smart people do foolish things?
Liberals show a greater gap between explicit attitudes and implicit attitudes and behavior than do conservatives.
So what is "implicit bias," and how is it different from the more overt bias we typically focus on when discussing racism in this country?
Use the adjective implicit when you mean that something is understood but not clearly stated.
prove capable or fit; meet requirements
to modify or restrict
This serious situation requires those who qualify to prove that their condition is either terminal or that it has or will continue for five years.
"Leviathan" was shown quietly in just one St. Petersburg theater last year to qualify for the Oscars.
In one sense, it means to be right for, to measure up. In another sense, though, qualify means to change something slightly, to limit it or add a condition to it.
n. corruption by sensuality; intemperance; wild living
n. a wild gathering involving excessive drinking and promiscuity
Then he became the star of a reality TV show "Southern Charm," where there was plenty of drinking and debauchery.
Despite the stereotypes of partying and debauchery, there is much we can learn from them about how to make our own lives healthier.
Debauchery is a noun meaning crazy partying and wild nights, usually accompanied by a lot of alcohol. So you probably don't want to engage in any kind of debauchery the night before an exam.
inharmonious; in disagreement
Variation blossomed when the three dancers came together, casually strutting on releve while singing assorted tones: not quite dissonant, not quite harmonious, definitely beautiful.
The composition is dissonant and eerie, invoking fear in the listener, perhaps like the fear felt by people crossing the border.
If things don't go together well, you can call them dissonant. Dissonant voices are saying different things. Dissonant clothing choices clash. Dissonant chords lack harmony.
to convert into bone; to become rigid
"Consumer behaviors are starting to ossify on the web," wrote venture capitalist Fred Wilson in a blog post last year.
Impatience would ossify into anger, turning everything into monetary costs, and making these costs the basis for political opposition to a liberal state.

Ossify means to become bony. When a baby is born, some of their "bones" are actually soft cartilage, which allows for growth. As the child grows, these soft areas ossify into actual bone. From the literal "to become bony" meaning of ossify, we get the more figurative meaning: to become rigid or hardened.
extra; unnecessary
serving no useful purpose; having no excuse for being
Each decision must be reviewed by a second tribunal, a step reformers say is superfluous and should be eliminated.
"Which of these rights, I ask, would we wish to discard? Are any of them trivial, superfluous, unnecessary? Are any them un-British?"
Effective writing minimizes emotions, omits superfluous words, and is succinct.
When something is so unnecessary that it could easily be done away with, like a fifth wheel on a car or a fifth person on a double date, call it superfluous.
bold; impertinent; marked by casual disrespect
To his mind, Collins was everything that a solicitor should not be—impudent, unscrupulous, vulgar; a discredit to the profession.
The impudent child was detested by God and a shame to its parents and could bring destruction to its house and line.

We often call someone impudent if they're disrespectful, snotty, or inappropriate in a way that makes someone feel bad. If you know someone has just lost all their money on the stock market, don't be impudent and ask them how they're going to afford gas money for their yacht.
without preparation; on the spur of the moment
ad without advance preparation
In Zimbabwe, satirical writers such as Silvanos Mudzvova stage impromptu street theater performance as a way of evading censors and the police.
The adjective impromptu describes things done or said without previous thought or preparation.
frivolously shallow and disrespectful
It's easy to flippant about rights for others when you can take your own for granted.
The e-mails depict him both as terse chief executive and a sometimes flippant writer who sprinkled his messages with "awesome," "my bad" and "chill out."

When a parent scolds a teenager for missing a curfew or blowing off a test and the teen snaps back, "Whatever," you could say the teen is being flippant. His reply was casual to the point of sarcasm and disrespect.
to increase by growth or addition
These small details accrete, over the course of the film, into something like a moral force.
Once the core is in place, it steadily accretes solids and gas to eventually make a giant world.
grow together (of plants and organs)
mutual; shared; interchangeable
concerning each of two or more persons or things; especially given or done in return
To witness such reciprocal pride between a father and son - particularly between a father and son as tough as these two - is sweet.
An air service agreement would also encompass things like airport fees and other reciprocal arrangements between airlines and airports.
What do these principles mean for Cuba? Reciprocal respect for each country's political and economic systems, avoiding any form of interference.

Reciprocal describes something that's the same on both sides. If you and your sister are in a big fight on a long car trip, you might resolve it through a reciprocal agreement that you'll stop poking her and she'll stop reading road signs out loud
foul and run-down and repulsive; morally degraded
Conditions in the house were squalid, and the people were stripped of clothes and shoes to hinder their escape.
Those on board complained of squalid conditions, including overflowing toilets and food shortages.
a word that describes something distasteful, dirty, unattractive, and squalid behavior is dirty, too, like cheating on a test and lying about it.
existing as an essential constituent or characteristic
in the nature of something though not readily apparent
It's a common mistake to attribute other people's behavior to their inherent characteristics in this way.
Comedians have an inherent ability to observe human nature, Sundance Film Festival director John Cooper said.
"People have a right to know that's intrinsic or inherent," Caplan said.

We use the adjective inherent to describe attributes that are part of the essential nature of something. It's different from you being tall, rather than being a description, it has to be a quality and this quality is unchangeable.
a strict, overly academic teacher
The pedagogue, or tutor, was an elderly freedman, tall, lean, serious, grey-haired and grey-bearded.
When his father died in 1827 he gave lessons there like any everyday pianoforte pedagogue because he needed money for the support of his mother.

Pedagogue is another name for "teacher," but one who is strict, stiff or old-fashioned, as in a pedagogue who stands in the front of the room and lectures for the entire class period, boring the students to tears.
required by rule
n. the recipient of a mandate
It should be mandatory reading for all those interested in the work of think tanks, which means everyone interested in public policy.
Anyone without proof of vaccination who came in contact with the five at the clinic was put under a mandatory quarantine for 21 days.
In the US, attending school through the twelfth grade, driving on the right side of the road, and obtaining a social security number are all mandatory.
inescapable; unavoidable
Underneath the surface of the disruption debate lurks an ineluctable duality: the duality of stasis and instability.
The findings in the new study derive directly from the ineluctable connections of body and mind.
Huh? Are you scratching your head at this word? The ineluctable conclusion is that you haven't the faintest idea what it means. Ineluctable means impossible to avoid.
not allowing anything to pass through; impenetrable
or years researchers have been warning about the growing threat of "antibiotic resistance," when bacteria changes into so-called "super-bugs" that are impervious to existing antibiotics.
This does not mean that most children of immigrant origin are impervious to France's republican values and the Enlightenment ideas that underpin them.
An impervious surface is one that can't be penetrated. The word is often followed by "to," as in "His steely personality made him impervious to jokes about his awful haircut."
having or showing knowledge or understanding or realization or perception
Bonus: Your not being a natural kid person means you'll be more cognizant of the fact that not everyone will be thrilled by your kids.
For the entire state of California, the vaccine refusal rate is only 2.6%, indicating that most citizens are cognizant of the benefits of immunization.

If you are cognizant of what's going on at the table behind you in the lunchroom, that means you know they're plotting to throw peas at your head. If you are cognizant of something, you are aware of or informed about it.
doing good; generous in assistance to the poor
Too many sports franchise owners behave as if they beneficently "give" a living to the players.
He is beneficent and kindhearted, and can honestly say that he has "spilt not a drop of human blood in the whole world."

Beneficent is the type of act that helps others. If you're a beneficent person, you probably spend a lot of your time volunteering at soup kitchens or homeless shelters, helping people who are less fortunate than you are.
having many curves
Route 219, a sinuous road that traverses southeastern West Virginia, heads northward and takes in a bit of Maryland, for the project's geographic scope.
Mr. Abrahams, for example, plans to meet with a bodybuilder to compare his physiognomy to that of the sinuous statues.
Sinuous means winding or curvy. If you get lost on a sinuous mountain path, you'll need a compass or a GPS to figure out which direction leads back to camp.
something that is said or written that refers to or mentions another person or subject in an indirect way
passing reference or indirect mention
More common is, when the allusion is missed, the story loses its brilliance, its frission, sometimes it totally fails as a story.
Mr. Recchia called Mr. Grimm "a minority of one," an allusion to Republican leaders' efforts to distance themselves from his legal troubles.
Ewald gives us access to Hamlet's thought process, clarifying allusions and refreshing metaphors you may have never really heard or understood.
The main thing to remember is that an allusion is a brief hint or a quick mention. It's meant to bring to mind a particular subject, but it always avoids getting into it in great depth
official permission or approval
a mechanism of social control for enforcing a society's standards
t would be like the state saying to all medical doctors: 100 percent of patients will get well, or we'll punish and sanction you.
Our president doesn't want Congress to further sanction Iran because they might get mad and walk away from the Nuclear "negotiations. "
Sanction has two nearly opposite meanings: to sanction can be to approve of something, but it can also mean to punish, or speak harshly to. Likewise, a sanction can be a punishment or approval
a passage concluding a composition (in music)
Only when "Funny Girl" tacks on a coda is there anything truly poignant here, and that's strictly about the passage of time.
Perhaps justice demanded a different coda, a sequel to redeem the suspect's questionable dexterity or enshrine it for all time.
A coda is a concluding segment of a piece of music, a dance, or a statement. It's usually short and adds a final embellishment beyond a natural ending point. Like this.
a collection of things (goods or works of art etc.) for public display
a systematic interpretation or explanation (usually written) of a specific topic
(music) the section of a movement (especially in sonata form) where the major musical themes first occur
How do you write something that could be called a time travel story without getting stuck in exposition or explanation of how it works?
Saffire Events, the company that will do the work, provides the service for many fairs and expositions, she said.
Rauner's team also hosted an exposition at a downtown convention center to showcase Illinois businesses, tourist attractions and universities.

An exposition takes place when you want to show something - like at a fair or convention for showing off goods, art, or similar wares. An exposition can also be the section of a story that explains the basics of the tale.
an expert able to appreciate a field
A connoisseur's group, not a populist one, the Hagen has made a number of gripping recordings and toured Europe extensively.
I fancy myself to be a chocolate chip cookie connoisseur but it's not really a skill that I can promote on a resume.
A connoisseur is a person who, through study and interest, has a fine appreciation for something
truthfulness
The veracity of the confession, though, is tempered by Hernandez's history of mental illness.
On "60 Minutes Wednesday," Rather offered documents critical of Bush's military service, but critics questioned the veracity of those files.

Veracity is linked to the adjective veracious or "truthful." But don't confuse veracious with voracious. A voracious person eats very large amounts of food. If you were veracious, or "truthful," you'd tell them they look fat.
an opinion that all the members of a group agree with
There is a general consensus among teachers about the need for greater security in schools.
Dr. King once said, "A genuine leader is not a searcher for consensus but a molder of consensus."
They must not shirk that responsibility by simply saying experts disagree when "someone in the world" disagrees with the consensus among experts.
When there's a consensus, everyone agrees on something. If you're going to a movie with friends, you need to reach a consensus about which movie everyone wants to see.
a wicked, sinful, depraved person
Reprobate describes the condition of one who has become insensible to reproof, and who is morally abandoned and lost beyond hope of recovery.
This is thought to be what's behind the behavior of most reprobate athletes because the fact is, they are outside of the rules.
There's no way around it, a reprobate is a bad egg. The black sheep of the family, missing a moral compass - a reprobate's been called everything from a deviant to an evildoer to a scoundrel.
unable to pay one's bills
Greece does not want to accept more bailout loans, because they are counterproductive for an insolvent country.
The Senate bill would still require other entities to pay for some damages the insolvent party can't cover.

Piggy bank empty? Nothing but lint in your pockets? Then you're probably unable to meet any financial obligations. In other words, you are insolvent. Being insolvent isn't just about being poor. A person or business that's insolvent has no resources, no assets and no way to pay any of the bills.
to take a claim of disagreement to court
"North Carolina did not litigate its cases. They should have as much right to petition the Supreme Court for review as Virginia has."
They decide whether to litigate in court if they want to stop the transaction.
To litigate is to engage in some sort of legal proceedings. If you're litigating, you'd better have a lawyer: you're involved in some sort of legal situation.
doubtful or questionable
Computing the penalty itself shouldn't be particularly problematic. From a mathematical perspective, it's going to be pretty simple
A recent study from researchers at Columbia University concluded that wheat proteins besides gluten may also trigger problematic symptoms in people with celiac disease.
Something problematic poses a problem or causes difficulties. Your ambitions to become the next great leader of Spain are great, but your inability to speak Spanish might prove problematic.
charming in a rustic way, naturally peaceful
excellent and delightful in all respects
Remodelista rounds up 11 of Italy's most idyllic farmhouses to rent for a relaxing retreat.
The Harry Potter author's novel is set in the idyllic fictional village of Pagford but reveals a town at war.
A week at the beach that goes perfectly is an idyllic vacation. Idyllic means so wonderful it seems almost magical.
to feel or express great sadness or disappointment about sth/sb
a song, poem or other expression of great sadness for sb who has died or sth that has ended
She laments that too many young women these days are trying to emulate the Kardashians instead of channeling their inner Mary Ann.
Participants are asked to distill their "experiences, questions, hopes, dreams, laments, or observations about race and identity" into a six word sentence.
Mourning will not accomplish anything; in fact it will probably empower terrorists knowing that their targets will not retaliate but just congregate together and lament.
If you are really upset or sorry about something, you might lament it. A lament is full of regret and grief
to carry out
Plans are then put into place so that people know how to implement the decision.
Right now, my focus is on completing and implementing the law, which we believe is the law.
The noun implement is a very useful word to describe anything as a tool or a thing that helps you do something. A knife and fork are implements for handling food.
to confirm, to back up with evidence
He also acknowledged that some officers in the department might feel pressure to lie in order to corroborate a partner's story.
He added that investigators were interviewing others to corroborate the man's story, as well as examining evidence from the scene.
If you swear to your teacher that you didn't throw the spitball, and your friends corroborate your story by confirming that you were concentrate to your homework, she might actually believe you.
cutting right to the heart of the matter
He is an incisive writer and a disciplined and decorous filmmaker, framing and cutting his scenes with clean, almost classical economy.
Justice Kagan is likely to ask incisive questions, as she is an expert in the issue at its core.
The adjective incisive describes something that is sharp, decisive, and direct. A comment that cuts right to the bone can be just as incisive as an actual knife.
threatening or foreshadowing evil or tragic developments; deadly or sinister
In Japan, the flow of data has shown the economy still suffering the baleful effects of a sales tax hike in April.
At the time, Jamaican politicians were able to point to baleful threats coming from Washington as a reason not to move forward.
Baleful means the foreshadowing of tragic or evil events. If no one's listening in class and your teacher reprimands you with a baleful glance, expect a pop quiz.
being everywhere equidistant and not intersecting
n. something having the property of being analogous to something else
The dancers keep their legs parallel and their movements mainly small.

In math, parallel means two lines that never intersect - think of an equals sign. Figuratively, parallel means similar, or happening at the same time. A story might describe the parallel lives of three close friends.
not strict or firm; careless or negligent; loose or slack
The review said the classification officer was lax about keeping his staff current on guidelines for determining what information must be kept secret.
Some websites take a lax attitude towards content, publishing for the sake of profit," CAC said in the statement.
That dad who buys beer for his teenage kids? His parenting style might be described as lax. A paperclip chain used as a bike lock? That would be an example of lax security.
shameful wickedness or depravity
It said U.S. authorities may refuse passengers admission for various reasons, including drug use and "moral turpitude."
Furthermore, allegations that he used campaign donations for personal use could be considered a "crime of moral turpitude," Cook wrote.

If you are guilty of turpitude, you should be ashamed of yourself. Turpitude is a word that represents depraved behavior. Prisons are filled with criminals who have engaged in acts of moral turpitude.
n. someone who exhibits great independence in thought and action; a rebel
independent in behavior or thought
Despite his reputation for being a maverick, the pope also knows he has to listen to advice.
He dreaded those flights, often piloted by mavericks who flew into clouds without knowing what was on the other side.

A maverick is a rebel, someone who shows a lot of independence. Someone who acts very independently is a maverick, and individual actions that stand out are maverick, as in "her maverick jumping style on the ice was both wild and delicate."
unpredictable; likely to change at any moment
Death was capricious; one friend was at the wrong place at the wrong time, a fine line between getting that image and getting killed.
The last time such capricious and arbitrary punishment was handed out was during the French Revolution.
Capricious is an adjective to describe a person or thing that's impulsive and unpredictable, like a bride who suddenly leaves her groom standing at the wedding altar.
extravagant or wasteful, especially with money
What Ford-like advances are not taking place precisely because politicians are so spendthrift with the money of others?
A natural spendthrift, he'd run out of money, and had great hopes for the English publication.

A spendthrift person is reckless and wasteful with his money. Spendthrifts who like to take you out to nice lunches are good people to be friends with, but it's generally a bad way to handle your own bank account.
frugal; thrifty
We see this happen all the time, where it can be sometimes more economical to send your child somewhere else other than your state institutions.
Recycling is the most economical option for you, besides being good for the environment.

Someone who is economical avoids wasting things, like money or food. So if someone sees you wrapping up a bite of food that could be part of tomorrow's lunch, don't let him call you "cheap." Tell him you are economical.
n. a disagreeable or noxious vapor; an escaping gas
Dorothy buried her face in the roses to get rid of the effluvium of such vulgarity.
Since the effluvium seeping out of the tire factory's chimney was invisible, park officials took months to realize fumes were killing hundreds of birds.
Effluvium is a smelly gas, vapor, or an exhalation. You wouldn't want to breathe in the effluvium from a cargo ship or you might become ill. Stick to sailing.
hard to understand; over one's head
These, and many other folks in many fields, seem to have a secret, recondite knowledge attached to a public presence.
A pair of actors trapped in a recondite play with no hint of plot or narrative.

If it's really hard to comprehend, then it's safe to say it's recondite. In the same family as "abstruse," "esoteric" and "totally deep, man," recondite is a very serious word that you could use to describe obscure philosophy books, high level mathematical theory... - things that make your brain hurt.
deprive through death
Stay in touch through phone calls, visits and cards, and remind the bereaved that you're thinking about them and their loved one who died.
What do you say to the bereaved family at a funeral, for instance?
if sb is bereaved, a relative or close friend has died
unimaginative; unfruitful; infertile
deficient in originality or creativity; lacking powers of invention
I expected something gritty and grimy, but this place looked more sterile than a doctor's office.
We have the Tower, but it's an empty, sterile place

A sterile person can't have kids, and a sterile environment is bland and boring. In both cases, sterile means lifeless. And a surgeon's instruments better be sterile - meaning they're free from germs and bacteria.
integrity; uprightness; honesty
Few artists of his international standing so consistently combined formal daring and ethical probity with an agitator's temperament.
Mandela was a man of probity and did not die wealthy.

If you show fiscal probity, it means you are responsible and ethical with your money. The story of George Washington chopping down the cherry tree and refusing to lie about it is a story of probity. The story was first told by a pastor, who may have made the whole thing up according to today's scholars, possibly to sell books –– no act of probity.
to deceptively persuade someone to do something he or she doesn't want to do
Mrs Obama urged her audience in Atlanta to cajole relatives, neighbours and friends from church to turn out in November.
My job is not to cajole, demand, and resolve myself, or my family, into perfection.

To cajole someone is to persuade them by using insincere compliments or promises. The origin of this word is probably a blend of two French words meaning "to chatter like a jaybird" and "to lure into a cage." When you cajole that guy into lending you some money, picture him as the bird going into the cage.
to swing back and forth; to fluctuate
Her confidence in the project fatally wounded, the rest of the process would see her oscillate between extreme self-aggrandizement and explosive temper.
We sleep and wake; our blood pressure, body temperature, and hormonal secretions oscillate; even the composition of breast milk changes from morning to evening.

On a hot day, you'll be happy to have a fan that can oscillate, meaning it moves back and forth in a steady motion. The word also can be used to describe a different kind of motion - the wavering of someone who is going back and forth between conflicting beliefs or actions.
natural or family relationship
To describe it as going from the sublime to the ridiculous comes closer, but fails to reveal the contradictory kinship between these events.
She had a few frightening encounters with people she met along the way, but also experienced kinship and kindness.
Kinship is a family relationship. You might describe the wonderful, close kinship you have with your favorite cousin.
rebirth or revival
Hopper was also a Renaissance man who never lost his wild, rebellious nature.
Artworks, and marvelous architecture, are everywhere in Florence, the enduring heritage of its Renaissance glory.
The period of European history at the close of the Middle Ages and the rise of the modern world; a cultural rebirth from the 14th through the middle of the 17th centuries
someone chosen to judge and decide a disputed issue
someone with the power to settle matters at will
The Better Business Bureau, which was established in 1912, is a non-profit organization that serves as an arbiter between consumers and businesses.
They buy patents from inventors and each other, creating a marketplace that checks big tech companies' sway, and rely ultimately on a fair arbiter: courts.
The law is the final arbiter of what is considered obscene.
An arbiter is someone selected to judge and settle a dispute. When Doc and Grumpy disagreed over whose turn it was to stay late at the mine, they chose Snow White as an arbiter
fertile; productive
Beyond this Brazil remains an overwhelmingly fecund source of talented footballers.
Those that most strongly biased toward males had particularly fecund sons, yielding 2.7 times more grandchildren than the sons of mothers that didn't bias.
The adjective fecund describes things that are highly fertile and that easily produce offspring or fruit. Rabbits are often considered to be fecund animals.
avoiding waste, economical
Frugal shopping is often associated with coupons, deals and everyday purchases.
China's consumers are notoriously frugal, with a household savings rate among the highest in the world for a large economy.
A person who lives simply and economically can be called frugal. Buying clothes at a consignment shop would be considered frugal.
n. the combination of ideas into a complex whole
Two earlier Rodgers and Hammerstein musicals, "Oklahoma!" and "Carousel," had been smashes, bringing a new synthesis of drama, music and dancing to Broadway.
It is the synthesis of these two opposite worlds into a functioning whole that is the key to meaningful, purposeful and productive organizations.
Synthesis is the act of combining elements to form something new. If you describe your bedroom decor as a synthesis of Andy Warhol and Punk Rock, we'll know you mean a mixture of these two styles.
to divide a state or county into election districts to gain political advantage
Before 1993, there was no such thing in constitutional law as an unconstitutional racial gerrymander separate and apart from a claim of vote dilution.
He lost, and afterward helped gerrymander his senate district to include more white voters, giving him a better path to the U.S.

Some politicians change the boundaries of their voting districts in order to benefit themselves or their political party. To manipulate the boundaries like this - often viewed as unfair - is to gerrymander.
nearness
The other main theory in social psychology predicts that people choose their friends on the basis of propinquity, or geographical closeness.
The Teutonic peoples were comparatively free from the infection, although the propinquity of the Rhinelands to France led to occasional visitations.
Ah propinquity, a word meaning "proximity or physical closeness." Your propinquity to someone in a conversation will affect whether you can smell his breath or not.
a beginner
"I don't think that the group in the locker room looks at our freshman class as a bunch of neophytes," Thompson said.
We need adults back in power - the neophytes have done sufficient damage.
Look at the little freshies, said the football team captain to his friends. "Little neophytes come to learn how the big boys play....Let's get 'em!"
hardworking; busy; diligent
He kept assiduous notebooks detailing the technical specifications of how film sets operate.
Vollmann remains very much the assiduous researcher, packing this book with authentic details.
If you call someone assiduous, it's a compliment. It means they're careful, methodical and very persistent. Good detectives are classically assiduous types.
n. comic, loose verse
A collection of the merest balderdash and doggerel that it was ever our bad fortune to lay eyes on.
This is doggerel indeed, and of a type that's hard to bear

We're not sure why poor dogs always seem to get used to describe something really dreadful, but it's the case with doggerel — meaning irregularly rhyming, really bad poetry, usually comic in tone and fit only for dogs.
spontaneous movement
Motility - the ability to move proficiently - is key for sperm to reach their destination, an egg.
However, sperm quality - in terms of both numbers and friskiness, or motility - starts to decline around age 35

Often used to describe the ability of sperm to swim, motility is anything's ability to move or get around. An easy way to remember that motility means the ability to move oneself without help is the mot- at the root of the word. It's the same root as that found in "motor," which is, of course, the engine that drives a car.
to urge forcefully; to taunt someone into doing something
n. a verbalization that encourages you to attempt something
They asked whether the standards should be set higher as a way to goad the teams further.
I tried to goad Microsoft engineers into telling me whether either of these would be improved in the final product, but they wouldn't say.

A goad is a pointy stick or other instrument used to prod something along. To goad is to poke something with that pointy stick. Either way, the pointiness is really essential for making things leap into action.
easily managed or controlled; obedient
I am persuaded that you will find in him an obedient and tractable son.
It's huge to show it's a tractable, manageable problem.

If your little brother quietly obeys your instructions and waits for you at the food court while you and your friends wander around the mall, he's probably a tractable child, meaning he's obedient, flexible, and responds well to directions.
n. insulting or abusive speech
And the stuff that came out of his mouth was some of the most outrageous, racist invective many of the men had ever heard.
But before we aim our collective invective at Sony or its online gaming peers, it's helpful to review the pathology.
Invective is harsh, abusive language, like, "you dirty rotten scoundrel." I'm sure you can think of harsher and more obscene examples, but we won't get into them here.
n. a self-evident rule or truth; a widely accepted saying
Economists' axiom that markets seek equilibrium, for example, is a puzzle to many natural scientists who look at living systems and see only disequilibrium.
It has become an axiom that as children mature they lose their sense of imagination
An axiom is a statement that everyone believes is true, such as "supply equals demand" or "the only constant is change." Mathematicians use axiom to refer to established proofs.
suing sarcasm or irony
Even in his creative work he had a satiric bent; his early training and associations, too, had been in journalistic satire.
The Onion stopped publishing its print edition in 2013, in spite of its satiric boast that print revenues were up "5,000 percent."
exposing human folly to ridicule
marked by the exercise of good judgment or common sense in practical matters
He is judicious and does not choose controversy until left without option.
His carefully cultivated persona was of a uniquely thoughtful, judicious, deliberative, evidence-driven man comfortable with complexity.
If you're judicious, you've got a good head on your shoulders and make good decisions. Humpty Dumpty's decision to sit on a wall? NOT judicious.
frantic, frenzied
But he is still trying to figure out an American culture that is more frenetic and obstreperous than in his homeland.
But according to a survey from Thomson Reuters Thomson Reuters, this calm performance was hiding some frenetic, behind the scenes activity.
The adj frenetic is another way to say frenzied, frantic, or totally worked up. Kind of how you'd run around the kitchen madly trying to cook a last-minute dinner for 30 of your closest friends.
disgusting or repulsive
Over the years, I've read dozens, maybe hundreds, of emails from employees who either complain about their bosses, or offer fulsome praises.
"The shooting incident in Ferguson, Missouri this weekend deserves a fulsome review," Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said in a statement.
Compliments usually make you feel pretty good, but fulsome compliments, which are exaggerated and usually insincere, may have the opposite effect.
violent breakdown; sudden overthrow
The failure to inspire and empower belief is what drove the recent debacle at The New Republic.
After the debacles of Obamacare, the failed stimulus package, and a host of other fiascoes, the obvious response is, "No, thanks."

Use debacle to refer to a violent disaster or a great failure. If the flower gardens come toppling down during prom, strangling some students and tripping others, you might call the evening a debacle.
n. an indirect expression; use of wordy or evasive language
After much circumlocution, gesticulation, and shouting on both sides, the two at last understand each other.
She avoided all circumlocution and made a direct application to him for a drawing of the whole park to send to her brother in Saxony.

Circumlocution is a long, complicated word which means a long, complicated way of expressing something. So circumlocution is speaking in circles, going round and round in a wordy way without ever getting to the heart of the matter.
to show sth clearly, esp a feeling, an attitude or a quality
easy to see or understand
a list of goods or passengers on a ship or plane
The anger he felt is manifest in his paintings.
The buildings in Rome manifest a high level of architectural sophistication.

Choose the word manifest when someone shows sth for everyone to notice. As an adj, manifest is a formal way to say that sth is apparent to the senses and is synonymous with evident, apparent, or clear
spread or diffuse through
pass through
penetrate mutually or be interlocked
"Let's spread that out and really have it permeate the whole team to where that's who we are."
As mobile devices continue to permeate our personal lives, the demand for corporate mobile apps continues to rise.
Many organizations would like to create more innovative teams or to have a more innovative culture permeate the organization.
The verb permeate literally means to "pass through." It's often used to describe smells or liquids that not only pass through, but also spread to fill an entire area.
extremely dry; unimaginative; dull
A huge desalination plant is under construction just outside the city that is expected to provide 7% of the arid region's water needs.
The day of the show was hot and arid, with an unrelenting desert sun blazing in a cloudless sky.
Arid is so dry that nothing will grow. Death Valley in California features an arid climate, which is why it's called Death Valley and not Life Valley.
an order of events from earliest to latest
To understand the significance of what happened today, let's review a highly simplified chronology of this complicated case.
The album's first six songs are a chronology of the breakup: feeling the partnership crumble and, eventually, coming to terms with it.
A chronology is like a timeline: it tells what happened when. A chronology of your day would begin when you wake up and end when you go to sleep. Hopefully, something interesting happened in between.
Unbiased; unaffected by self-interest
Disinterested means unbiased or impartial; uninterested means bored or indifferent.
"Yet neither of us can claim to be disinterested observers. We both have a long history with Marshall."

If you can't decide whether to purchase the shirt with orange polka dots or the purple paisley-patterned one, you might seek input from a disinterested, or unbiased, party (who will probably tell you not to buy either one).
to find or show the relationship of two things.
Owning an Amazon Kindle is also correlated with increased Amazon.com spending.
Certain personality traits such as conscientiousness appear to correlate to dog ownership, for instance

f you notice that crumbs appear on your little brother's shirt whenever the cookies disappear from the cookie jar, you can say that you've correlated two facts, meaning that you've established or revealed that they're linked in a way that explains both of them.
softly bright or radiant
The fish is known for it's luminous fishing hook, which attracts smaller fish.
Her face lit up; she was so pale, so luminous under the streetlight, that wasn't just an expression
Luminous means full of or giving off light. During the winter holidays, with all their emphasis on light, you can see luminous displays of candles everywhere.
lacking prudent foresight; not given careful consideration
As a result of all these fiscally improvident behaviors, they have less money than men.
He could sometimes be shortsighted and improvident, but, like the prizefighter he nearly became, he always bounced back slugging.

Someone who is improvident doesn't worry about the future - or plan wisely for it. If you spend all your money on video games even though you know you have to buy your mom a birthday present next week, you have made an improvident decision.
showing too much support for one person or group, esp without considering it carefully
a member of an armed group that is fighting secretly against enemy soldiers who have taken control of its country
Given how sluggish things happen in Congress - made worse by partisan politics - I don't hold out much hope that the policy will come to pass.
It was a very partisan speech, even though the president said he was going to offer policies that were "practical, not partisan".
Supporters told the committee the current system minimizes partisan politics in selecting justices and shouldn't be changed.

If something is prejudicial towards a particular point of view, you can call it partisan. You'll often hear of the partisan politics in the US - since politicians seem to be so devoted to either the Republican or Democratic parties
to sharpen
And as your business grows, you will need to continually hone your leadership skills.
The researchers drew on three global datasets to try to hone in on land's changing contribution to global warming.
The verb hone means to sharpen skills. When you practice shooting baskets every day after school, you are honing your skills as a basketball player.
an embankment designed to prevent the flood of a river
a formal reception of visitors or guests (as at a royal court)
When the river is high, specially designed gates would be opened in the river levee, allowing freshwater and sediment to wash over nearby areas.
She opposes his tsunami-protection levee plan and enjoys Korean culture while he battles with Seoul.
A levee is an embankment, like a dam, constructed to prevent the overflow of a body of water. It can also mean a formal reception
to delay or stop the progress of sth
block passage through
That type of barrier to travel would impede business and tourism – and cost jobs.
To impede something is to delay or block its progress or movement. Carrying six heavy bags will impede your progress if you're trying to walk across town.
to promote the growth or development of
providing or receiving nurture or parental care though not related by blood or legal ties
This action is expected to add some further support to demand, so as to foster sustainable growth and inflation outcomes consistent with the target
Some foster parents said they object to the influenza vaccine because they believe it is "experimental" and poses potential side effects.
To foster is to nurture something for a little while. She fosters creativity by providing crayons to every student. You can also foster a child, which means she lives in your home for a time.
to convert someone from one religion or doctrine to another; to recruit converts to a religion or doctrine
The filmmaker is shooting "Silence," a story of Jesuit missionaries attempting to proselytize in 17th-century Japan.
And then they proselytize about fiscal responsibility and blame "the others" for their sin.
To proselytize is to try to persuade someone to switch to your religious beliefs or your way of living. If you are going to proselytize, try not to be too pushy!
excessively conspicuous; showing off
(of a display) tawdry or vulgar
They drove the biggest cars, wore the most flamboyant clothing, and built the most ostentatious houses.
And while Matthews may add a touch of the ostentatious, Wagner will do things far more quietly, yet just as fiercely.

No one wants to be described as ostentatious, a word whose cousins include pretentious, flamboyant, and gaudy. Someone wailing especially loudly at a funeral of a distant acquaintance might be making an ostentatious show of sorrow.
an aberration; an irregularity; a deviation
a person who is unusual
Lightning Rods is therefore that true anomaly in fiction: a novel that works beautifully despite having no real characters, no real conflict, no real story.
I do most of my work in Google Docs, Sheets, and Gmail, but I'm an anomaly; most professionals use Word, Excel, and Outlook.
An anomaly is an abnormality, a blip on the screen of life that doesn't fit with the rest of the pattern.
to deny; to speak or act against
No theory can gainsay the vital transformation which we feel taking place within us through their agency.
While this makes him sound more like a case for psychoanalysis than an entertainer, it's impossible to gainsay the phenomenal results he creates onstage.
Gainsay, a verb, means "contradict" or "speak out against." When you challenge authority, you gainsay, as in teachers don't like it when unruly students gainsay them.
differing in opinion; deviating
The project marks the intersection of two businesses on divergent paths.
A teacher who comes to work in a clown outfit is being divergent; a clown who comes to work in a business suit is also being divergent.
Something divergent is moving away from what is expected. Two divergent paths are moving in opposite directions — away from each other.
just beginning; not organized or orderly
Cole is a man out of the story's frame, out of reach and thus too inchoate to earn our compassion.
Portraying the Penguin in his inchoate stage, Taylor has been free to bring the role a fresh approach.

Inchoate means just beginning to form. You can have an inchoate idea, like the earliest flickers of images for your masterpiece, or it can be a feeling, like the inchoate sense of anger toward your new neighbor's talking parrot.
a powerful argument made in refutation of something
of or involving dispute or controversy
They also declared it would be a place free of "all party-cant-words, polemics and controversy, religious, national and political."
For a long time, I admired his insightful science writing, his fierce polemics, his uncompromising passion for the truth.
A polemic is something that stirs up controversy by having a negative opinion, usually aimed at a particular group. A piece of writing can be a polemic, as long as it gets someone's goat.
sweetly flowing
I wondered if this could be that warm sensation I feel when listening to Ms. Streisand's mellifluous renditions of "People" or "On a Clear Day?"
A charismatic speaker, she addressed the villagers in the booming and mellifluous cadences of Liberian English.
Use the adjective mellifluous to describe something that sounds sweet and smooth, like the honeyed voice of a late-night radio DJ.
to cause or produce; to engender
Buckets beget more buckets, until everyone is taking a public ice shower.
In "A Brief History of Seven Killings," tragedy seems to come full-circle as acts of horrendous violence beget more violence.
To beget means to generate something, usually children. Although it can be used to refer to anything that generates something else - for example, an inspiration can beget a brilliant idea.
n. an artistic class or category
This attitude has allowed the festival to organically expand to include different genres of music, film, and technology.
The two genres each have their strengths, and each does things better than the other.
A genre is a specific type of music, film, or writing. Your favorite literary genre might be science fiction, and your favorite film genre might be horror flicks about cheerleaders. Go figure.
vanishing or fading; scarcely perceptible
The civil rights issue is not an ephemeral, evanescent domestic issue that can be kicked about by reactionary guardians of the status quo, King said.
Now I know for sure that the soul is an evanescent thing and the body is its temporary container, because I saw it.
A beautiful sunset, a rainbow, a wonderful dream right before your alarm clock goes off - all of these could be described as evanescent, which means "fleeting" or "temporary."
n. a harsh-sounding mixture of words, voices, or sounds
"Saturday Night Live" is a sloppier operation, a cacophony of voices and styles jumbled together.
The sounds form a cacophony of construction - jackhammers' percussive pelting, the persistent beeping of vehicles in reverse, and buzzsaws shrill screams.

A cacophony is a jarring, discordant mix of sounds that have no business being played together. When the orchestra tunes up before a show, it sounds like a cacophony because each musician is playing a completely different tune, at different times, and at different volumes.
stubborn; inflexible
Mr Geithner will not convince his most strident critics, but less obdurate readers will find his advice invaluable.
Granite is a hard, obdurate stone, high in acidity.
Obdurate is a formal word meaning stubborn. If you want to major in English, but your parents are obdurate that you should go premed, they might go so far as to threaten not to pay your tuition.
to confuse, deject, frustrate, deceive
Environment Wine and Climate Change Every day, it seems, global warming finds a new way to discomfit us.
Later, at a bar with Adam's casemates, she awkwardly announces that she was fired, to the plain discomfit of everyone else, not that she noticed.

To discomfit someone is to make them feel uncomfortable or upset. An easy way to discomfit another person is to use the age-old, childish trick of ignoring them. (Of course, we're sure you would never do that, right? Right?)
to conclude by reasoning, to deduce
Although we cannot yet infer any causal relationships, rising student debt levels have, to an extent, coincided with falling entrepreneurship rates among young people.
The participants were then asked to infer people's emotional states based on facial expressions and non-verbal cues.

When you infer, you listen closely to someone and guess at things they mean but haven't actually said. It's like guessing, but not making wild guesses but a well informed guess - if you see your mom's bag on the table, you might infer that she's home.
forceful; sharp or biting to the taste or smell
Korean food, particularly dishes pungent with kimchi, red pepper paste and fish sauce, is difficult to pair with wine.
Taleggio is a semisoft Italian cheese that grates easily and melts nicely and has a pungent aroma but mild, almost fruity flavor.

Use pungent to describe a taste or smell that gives a sharp sensation. Ginger and mustard seed are examples of pungent spices. And pungent can be used in a figurative sense: pungent language is stimulating and expressive.
unpredictable or wandering
The erratic weather pattern has put many skiers and snowboarders into panic mode, but there should be worthwhile options throughout the holidays.
Newton is the crazy, erratic and spoiled one who will never live up to his potential.
He was relatively new to the building; he had developed a reputation for erratic behavior in the hallways and was sometimes incoherent, two residents said.
The adjective erratic describes things that are unpredictable, unusual, and that deviate from the norm
n. a puzzle; a riddle; a difficult problem
Suddenly they were faced with the conundrum many new parents face: balancing careers and family life.
The good news for security professionals and executives who want to solve the cyber security conundrum is the use of data; specifically, big data analytics.

Conundrum is used to describe a riddle or puzzle, sometimes including a play on words or pun such as: "What walks on four legs in the morning, two in the afternoon, and three in the evening?" The answer is "A person": crawling as a child, walking as an adult, and using a cane in old age.
choosing or draw the best from many sources
The 18-song long album is an eclectic mix of everything from pop to rock, all with a vintage 60's vibe.
Don't be afraid to step out of your comfort zone and break the matching habit to create an appealing, eclectic look in your apartment

The word can refer to any assemblage of varied parts. You can have an eclectic group of friends, eclectic taste in furniture, or enjoy eclectic cuisine (fusion cooking that uses ingredients from different national cuisines)
cause to become widely known
Disseminate means to spread information, knowledge, opinions widely. Semin- derives from the Latin word for seed; the idea with disseminate is that information travels like seeds sown by a farmer.
n. a person from whom you are descended
to refrain from, to abstain
"I know not why it is, but my heart is so full for you all that I cannot forbear from writing to tell you.
He had his gun in his hand, but forbore to fire, lest he should alarm any Esquimaux who might possibly be in the neighborhood.
The grandson bears a physical resemblance to his forbear that has often been invoked to help solidify the public's embrace.
A forbear is an ancestor or any person you are descended from, like your grandfather or your great, great, great, great grandfather.
thick and sticky
She said she discovered the paste, which tastes and looks like peanut butter but is not quite as sweet or viscous, at a previous conference.
For egg whites, that's the viscous liquid form in a raw egg.
Viscous means sticky, gluey and syrupy. So if something is viscous, you usually don't want to stick your fingers in it — that goes for boogers and maple syrup alike.
original, unspoiled, pure
Inside, the walls and floors are pristine white, and the clear cases full of colorful candies pop out at you.
This collective approach to home decor has the effect of making everything appear pristine and cared for.
If something is pristine it's immaculately clean or has never been used. So please check your shoes before walking on a pristine white carpet.
making peace; attempting to resolve a dispute through goodwill
intended to placate
It was an important and almost conciliatory message, but one that was overshadowed - or undershadowed? - by the leader's shrunken eyebrows
Many viewed the cartoon image as a conciliatory message from the new editors of Charlie Hebdo after the carnage of the Paris attack.
Mr Zhao, who had a more liberal attitude than other leaders, favored a conciliatory approach towards the protesters

If you're in a fight with a friend and you want to end it, you should make a conciliatory gesture, such as inviting her to a party you're having. Conciliatory describe things that make other people less angry.
doubtful; bogus; false
intended to deceive
These records can help to protect the public in cases of officer misconduct. It also protects officers from spurious complaints.
He said they were "clearly spurious medications," and expressed frustration that scrutiny had fallen immediately on him.
The hospital said some families were giving spurious reasons for not taking their loved ones back.
Something false or inauthentic is spurious. Don't trust spurious ideas and stories. Spurious statements often are lies, just as a spurious coin is a counterfeit coin - a fake.
hard to understand or grasp
There are also people who can run a mile in under 4 minutes, who can learn to sing opera, and who can comprehend abstruse mathematics.
